text: Purpose: To compare complications in children up to 4 years old having cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implantation using 2 techniques: in-the-bag IOL with anterior vitrectomy or optic capture of IOL with no anterior vitrectomy.
sentences: Purpose: To compare complications in children up to 4 years old having cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implantation using 2 techniques: in-the-bag IOL with anterior vitrectomy or optic capture of IOL with no anterior vitrectomy.

text: I mprovements in techniques, technology, and surgeons' understanding of pediatric cataract management have led to better technical and functional outcomes. Despite this, visual axis obscuration (VAO) remains as 1 of the major obstacles that hamper visual rehabilitation, might induce amblyopia, [1] [2] [3] [4] and necessitate additional surgical procedures when using general anesthesia. Visual axis obscuration has been reported to be more frequent and severe when cataract surgery is performed at a younger age. [5] [6] [7] Therefore, constant efforts are being made by pediatric cataract surgeons to reduce or delay the onset of VAO, in particular in younger children. Performing a posterior capsulectomy and anterior vitrectomy has become a part of the routine surgical strategy for pediatric cataract management for the same reason in infants and children younger than 5 or 6 years. 8, 9 The rationale is to remove the scaffold of the posterior capsule and anterior vitreous face on which the proliferating lens epithelial cells (LECs) can migrate.

8, 9 The rationale is to remove the scaffold of the posterior capsule and anterior vitreous face on which the proliferating lens epithelial cells (LECs) can migrate.

text: Neuhann and Neuhann A first reported optic capture of an intraocular lens (IOL) in an adult with posterior capsule rupture. Subsequently, Gimbel and Debroff 10 described this technique for pediatric cataract surgery. Gimbel 11 also found that posterior continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis (PCCC) with optic capture of a heparin-coated IOL with no vitrectomy seemed to successfully prevent secondary VAO in children. Similarly, Raina et al. 12 found that optic capture of a poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) IOL could prevent VAO in children despite no anterior vitrectomy being performed. However, around the same time, there were other studies suggesting that optic capture with no anterior vitrectomy does not always ensure a clear visual axis in children younger than 5 years. 9, 13, 14 In previous studies, 3-piece or 1-piece PMMA IOLs of different configurations were used. 10, 15 An important factor in achieving optic capture as well as its ability to prevent LEC migration is the design of the IOL, especially the optic-haptic junction. 15 With newer foldable IOL materials and designs, there is renewed interest in the technique of optic capture in adults and children. [16] [17] [18] Therefore, we decided to revisit the technique of optic capture in children using a 3-piece hydrophobic acrylic IOL. The purpose of this study was to compare intraoperative and postoperative complications between the 2 techniques (in-the-bag IOL implantation with vitrectomy versus IOL optic capture with no vitrectomy) in a randomized fashion in children up to 4 years old.

text: This prospective randomized controlled clinical trial included children up to 4 years old having cataract surgery with IOL implantation for nontraumatic cataracts at Iladevi Cataract & IOL Research Centre, Ahmedabad, India, between April 2013 and March 2014. The institutional review board approved the study, which adhered to the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki. Informed consent was obtained from the parents or legal guardian before enrollment. The trial is registered on the National Institutes of Health Clinical Trials website. B Exclusion criteria were microcornea (horizontal corneal diameter !9.0 mm), previous ocular trauma and/or surgery, uveitis, preexisting intraocular pressure (IOP) higher than 25 mm Hg, coloboma, monocular patient, and a nondilating pupil. If the patient had bilateral cataract, only the first-operated eye was included in the study.

The eyes were randomized to have implantation of an in-the-bag IOL with limbal anterior vitrectomy (Group 1) or an optic capture of the IOL with no anterior vitrectomy (Group 2). An unscrubbed nurse informed the surgeon of the method of IOL implantation after cataract removal and before the PCCC was performed.

text: All surgeries were performed by the same surgeon (A.R.V.). A limbal paracentesis was created, and sodium hyaluronate 2.3% (Healon5) was injected in the anterior chamber. Two additional paracenteses were created at the 3 o'clock and 9 o'clock positions. A manual anterior CCC (ACCC) of approximately 4.5 to 5.0 mm was performed using a microincision capsulorhexis forceps under trypan blue staining in the absence of a red reflex. Bimanual irrigation/aspiration (I/A) was performed for lens removal, after which a 27-gauge cystotome was used to initiate a 4.0 to 4.5 mm PCCC, which was completed with a microincision capsulorhexis forceps. In eyes randomized to Group 1, a bimanual limbal anterior vitrectomy was performed. However, if vitreous disturbance was found, anterior vitrectomy was performed irrespective of the group allocation. Thereafter, the temporal incision was enlarged and a 3-piece hydrophobic acrylic IOL (Acrysof MA60AC, Alcon Laboratories, Inc.) was implanted.

text: Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS software (version 13, SPSS Inc.). Outcome measures were compared between the groups as a whole. For analysis, the patients were subclassified within each group according to age at surgery as follows: 1 year or younger or older than 1 year to 4 years or older. The Fisher exact test and a proportions test were used for analysis, and a P value less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

text: In Group 1, the IOL could be placed in the capsular bag in all eyes, with no major intraoperative complications. In Group 2, optic capture could not be achieved in 5 (16.12%) of 31 eyes randomized to have optic capture. Three of these had a posterior capsule plaque preventing a PCCC of desired size ( Figure 2) , and 2 had an inadvertently large PCCC. Of these 5 eyes, 3 had in-the-bag IOL implantation, 1 had placement of the haptics in the ciliary sulcus with the optic captured through the ACCC, and 1 had placement of the haptics in the ciliary sulcus with the optic captured through both capsulorhexes. An anterior vitrectomy was required in 3 of the 5 eyes because of vitreous disturbance during plaque excision.

text: Thirty eyes in Group 1 and 26 eyes in Group 2 were included for the comparative analyses of postoperative outcome measures. The 5 eyes in which optic capture was attempted but could not be achieved were analyzed separately. All children required an examination under anesthesia at every follow-up. Table 2 shows the cumulative VAO incidence at the 6-month and 12-month follow-ups, and Figure 3 shows an eye from each group in which the central visual axis is clear 12 months postoperatively. Clinically significant VAO occurred in only 1 eye in Group 1 during the study. This child had surgery at age 7.30 months for bilateral cataract. Significant VAO was detected 3 months postoperatively and pars plana membranectomy was performed 4 months postoperatively. Although the fellow eye was not included in the study, it had an in-thebag IOL implanted with anterior vitrectomy and did not require a secondary procedure.

text: The complications of pediatric cataract surgery, in particular VAO and inflammation, are usually more aggressive in infants and younger children. 21, 22 Therefore, we studied the complications of the 2 techniques in children up to 4 years old. Furthermore, in both groups, approximately 45% of the children were younger than 1 year at the time of cataract surgery.

text: In the current study, both groups maintained a clear visual axis and only 1 eye of an infant required a membranectomy in the first year postoperatively. With optic capture, there was no significant VAO, not even in infants and even though no anterior vitrectomy was performed. This is because the fusion of the anterior and posterior capsules leads to sequestration of LECs within the capsular fornices and prevents their migration to the intact anterior vitreous face. Our study results are similar to those in other recent nonrandomized studies, which have shown promising results for VAO prevention with optic capture in adults and children. [16] [17] [18] 23 In a previous study, 13 we found proliferation of LECs and projection onto the IOL 18 months after optic capture of a 1-piece PMMA IOL. In the current study, this phenomenon did not occur during the 12 months of follow-up. This might be attributable to the design of the 3-piece IOL, in particular its optic-haptic junction, thereby allowing almost 360 degrees of capsular fusion. However, a longer follow-up would be required to determine the outcome of the proliferating LECs trapped between the 2 capsules. In contrast with our previously published study in which there were more inflammatory sequelae in the capture group, 13 no difference was found in the incidence or severity of synechiae or cell deposits between the 2 groups.

text: A recent study of adult eyes 24 found that anterior chamber reaction, as measured by a laser flare meter, is lower when a primary PCCC is performed with posterior optic buttonholing than when a primary PCCC is performed with in-the-bag IOL implantation. The authors attribute this to the fusion of the anterior and posterior capsules, which traps the OVD behind the IOL and does not allow it to come into the anterior chamber and incite inflammation. A very important aspect to consider in children is the IOL material and design, including the optic-haptic junction configuration. The newer 3-piece foldable IOL designs might be better suited for optic capture. Furthermore, with better techniques, OVDs, and instrumentation there might be lesser iris manipulation, thus reducing postoperative inflammatory sequelae. Less inflammatory response might also be attributed to the use of triamcinolone in recent studies, [25] [26] [27] which was not used in previous studies.

text: Glaucoma developed in 2 eyes in Group 1 during the follow-up. Both children who developed glaucoma were younger than 1 year (6 months and 7 months, respectively) at the time of surgery. It is well known that a young age at surgery is a risk factor for glaucoma after cataract surgery, in particular in children younger than 6 months. 28 Severe, early postoperative inflammation could also be an independent risk factor for the development of inflammatory glaucoma. Our routine postoperative regimen included frequent and prolonged topical steroids and atropine, which might suppress severe early onset inflammation and thereby inflammatory glaucoma. Furthermore, we only had a follow-up of 12 months and glaucoma is known to manifest long after surgery, even up to 10 years postoperatively. [29] [30] [31] Thus, a longer follow-up would be required to assess the development of glaucoma.

text: Contrary to a previous study in which we found a partial or total loss of the optic capture in up to one-third of the eyes, 13 no eye in the current study showed a loss of capture. We believe this is the result of the slim optic-haptic junction of the 3-piece IOL as well as the more controlled PCCC size that was made by an experienced surgeon. In the present study, the major reason for being unable to achieve optic capture was the presence of a posterior capsule plaque that precluded performing an appropriately sized manual PCCC.

text: There have been significant improvements to anterior vitrectomy, such as high-cut-rate vitrectors and 23-to 25-gauge sutureless trocar-cannula systems. However, vitrectomy is an additional procedure and to our knowledge, there is still no good data available on its effect in small eyes, including its effect on the axial growth of the eye. There is some speculation that anterior vitrectomy might be associated with a higher risk for developing open-angle glaucoma in aphakic or pseudophakic eyes. 32 The proposed mechanisms for this are oxidative stress and an increased susceptibility of the optic nerve head to IOP in vitrectomized eyes. Therefore, any technique that can help achieve the objective of reducing VAO and avoiding an additional surgical maneuver would be helpful to surgeons. There are other techniques that can prevent or reduce VAO in young children without performing an anterior vitrectomy, including the bag-in-the-lens technique 33 and vertical entrapment of the IOL. 34 Both techniques are based on the principle of sequestering the LECs within the fused anterior and posterior capsule leaflets.

text: One limitation of this technique is that the surgeon must be able to create an adequately sized and centric PCCC. An ideal PCCC for optic capture should be 1.0 mm smaller than the IOL optic diameter. This may be difficult for beginner surgeons and is especially challenging in infants younger than 6 months. Thus, surgeons wanting to start off with this technique might consider children older than 6 months. Often, the presence of posterior capsule plaques, preexisting defects, or posterior lentiglobus preclude a desired size of manual PCCC. The technique of optic capture does have a significant learning curve. Furthermore, because it is best suited for 3-piece foldable IOLs, it might preclude the use of certain IOLs such as toric IOLs, which at present are mainly available in the 1-piece design. However, with greater surgical experience and confidence, posterior optic capture is a technique worth having in every surgeon's armamentarium, and can be performed wherever feasible, depending on the surgeon's comfort. This can reduce or delay the VAO without having to perform an anterior vitrectomy. Most studies of children used older 1-piece PMMA IOLs, and there are no randomized head-to-head comparisons between optic capture and the conventional in-the-bag IOL using newer IOL designs, in particular in younger children for whom anterior vitrectomy has become the norm during congenital cataract surgery. Some previous studies concluded that optic capture is ineffective in reducing VAO without a vitrectomy, and it might even lead to more inflammatory sequelae.
